data.title: Menu Bar Resets to Visible When Reopening Window
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.9.0 Commit 27240e71ef390bf2d66307e677c2a333cebf75af
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VSCode window
2. Set user setting `"window.menuBarVisibility": "hidden"`, which should make the menubar hidden
3. Close VSCode
4. Reopen VSCode, the menu bar is now visible

data.title: Theme & theme extension problem in 1.9
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9
- OS Version: Windows 10

Just upgraded to 1.9 and noticed that my custom theme become 'broken'. It is no longer support distinct colors. Original theme supports it but mine is not. Also it seems the whole approach to css is changed. Please see screenshots below.
![theme_original](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3128894/22576508/cec7c124-e989-11e6-8bc5-39d26829ff68.png)
![theme_custom](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3128894/22576507/cec772d2-e989-11e6-97a5-2e30a1cebf2a.png)


More important I can't debug theme extension to fix it. When trying to debug (f5) it doesn't lunch another instance of visual studio code to select theme. Is there any guidelines to edit theme extensions post 1.9?

data.title: Empty launch.json causes files to take a few seconds to save
data.body:
I have noticed the latest version 1.9.0 on Windows 10 and OSX 10.11 seems to taking quite a while to save a file. After I hit save, it usually takes about 4 seconds before the editor dirty dot goes away. If I try to close the editor before it goes away, I get a dialog about unsaved changes. I'm pretty sure this isn't just a UI bug as I have to wait the 4 seconds or so before being able to run commands using that file and its changes.

This happens to all files including settings and such. I have tested it with and without extensions.

- VSCode Version: 1.9.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 and OSX 10.11

data.title: Yellow lightbulb always asking to add include path
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: Latest, 1.9.0
- OS Version: OSX 10.12

Hi, I just noticed (maybe it's recent) that every time I type a new line in a .c file on vscode (or even when I clic on a function name), there is the yellow lightbulb that appears and that asks me to add an include path to the settings. But possible includes specified .. I can't get rid of it and it's driving me crazy.

Here is my c_cpp_properties.json :
```

{
    "configurations": [
        {
            "name": "Mac",
            "includePath": ["/usr/include", 
            "/Users/XXX/XXX/XXX/includes",
             "/Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer/Platforms/MacOSX.platform/Developer/SDKs/MacOSX10.12.sdk/usr/include"],
            "browse" : {
                "limitSymbolsToIncludedHeaders" : false,
                "databaseFilename" : ""
            }
        },
        {
            "name": "Linux",
            "includePath": ["/usr/include"],
            "browse" : {
                "limitSymbolsToIncludedHeaders" : true,
                "databaseFilename" : ""
            }
        },
        {
            "name": "Win32",
            "includePath": ["c:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Visual Studio 14.0/VC/include"],
            "browse" : {
                "limitSymbolsToIncludedHeaders" : true,
                "databaseFilename" : ""
            }
        }
    ]
}
```

data.title: Fix #19769 - adopt typescript's noUnusedLocals
data.body: Blocked on a TS issue, here for safekeeping, to accept when it's fixed.

data.title: terminal.integrated.commandsToSkipShell is unintuitive

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
The `commandsToSkipShell` setting requires users to override the entire list, this sucks for users as they need to add a bunch of stuff to their settings.json file, it sucks for us and users because the list can change between versions.

An example: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/19751

Maybe the ability to add and remove instead of setting an absolute list would be better? How would the default list be communicated if so?

I'm open to feedback on how to solve this :smile:

data.title: Switch from tslint's no-unused-variables to tsc's noUnusedLocals
data.body: Because the former prints a deprecation message now. Blocked on https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/13120 - all of our actions that are registered with a decorator will error as unused.

data.title: VSCode is quite slow to start
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.0 (27240e71ef390bf2d66307e677c2a333cebf75af, 2017-02-02T08:23:30.856Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-docker|PeterJausovec|0.0.7|
|scala|daltonjorge|0.0.4|
|githistory|donjayamanne|0.1.0|
|javadebugger|donjayamanne|0.0.2|
|python|donjayamanne|0.5.2|
|vscode-npm-script|eg2|0.0.21|
|json-tools|eriklynd|1.0.2|
|vscode-npm|fknop|3.3.0|
|code-runner|formulahendry|0.5.0|
|vscode-javac|georgewfraser|0.0.23|
|PowerShell|ms-vscode|0.7.2|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.5.2|
|Ruby|rebornix|0.10.1|
|java|redhat|0.0.7|
|startanyshell|remcoros|0.3.1|
|vscode-icons|robertohuertasm|4.0.1|
|HOCON|sabieber|0.0.1|

---

I set VSCode as the default editor for many file types, so that I can double click and have them open in VSCode :-) I noticed quite soon the impact on my workflow, i.e. the time spent waiting for files to open. For comparison I reverted back to Sublime Text as the default editor and the difference is very visible.

From a quick test using `time <command>` it appears that VSCode is at least twice as slow, and perhaps slower when the default editor is already open (i.e. the open instance could be reused to open the new file)

data.title: make renderMarkedString properly handle language='markdown'
data.body:
The [Language Server Protocol spec](https://github.com/Microsoft/language-server-protocol/blob/master/protocol.md#hover-request) doesn't say a language server can't return a `MarkedString` like `{language: 'markdown', value: '<some markdown>'}`. In fact, https://github.com/sourcegraph/go-langserver is a language server that currently returns `MarkedString` like that.

This change makes `renderMarkedString` properly handle rendering the special case above as markdown, *not* as some markdown code block. A string value for `MarkedString` will still be interpreted as markdown according to the spec.

|java|redhat|0.0.7|

|vscode-icons|robertohuertasm|4.0.1|
|HOCON|sabieber|0.0.1|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. enable ApplePressAndHoldEnabled (see http://lifehacker.com/5826055/make-your-keyboard-keys-repeat-properly-when-held-down-in-mac-os-x-lion) (this is enabled by default on all MacOS installations)
2. Hold down the "a" key
3. The editor shows only one "a" letter instead of "aaaaaaaaaaaaaa...."

somehow some applications are not affected by this annoyance, e.g. iTerm2. It would be nice if VSCode could do something about it.

data.title: Some Unicode characters like ß not working in terminal
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.0
- OS Version: Win 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open Terminal
2. Type bash on prompt
3. Type ß on german keyboard

The cursor jumps 4 places forward when typing ß in bash.exe called via powershell and reverting the mess with backspace is somehow out of sync. It only deletes two and then it thinks it is at the prompt. But it isn't yet.

data.title: Restrict quick open file to project files
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. ctrl+p
2. type index.html

I expect the first result to be the file in the current project folder (because 1. it is in local project, 2. it is the most recently opened, 3. most recently edited).

But it is a file that exist in completely different folder and not in the project. Because of this, I keep editing the wrong file.

data.title: Cannot reliably open a folder from CLI with `code .`
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.0
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VS Code
2. Close all CMD+W until all windows are gone, but app is still open
3. Issue `code .` from terminal

Expected Result: VS Code opens with folder pane expanded showing contents of $PWD from my shell, 
Actual results: New untitled document opens

data.title: [css] autocomplete adding an extra '-' when autocompleting
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.0-insider (27240e71)
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new CSS file
2. Create an empty CSS ruleset
3. Type `top: -2px` and press enter 

Expected Behavior:

Autocomplete should close and do nothing (e.g. the same behavior if you type `position: relative` and then press enter)

Actual Behavior:

You get `top: --2px`

data.title: Setting a terminal by workspace settings is broken! User settings are not sufficient!
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Upgrade to VSCode 1.9.0
2. Open Terminal

VSCode complains that my custom terminal settings in the workspace configuration are wrong after the update. It does not respect these anymore.

I need per project/workspace configuration because i use remote ssh terminals to work on the dev server. The dev server is different in every workspace.

This was perfectly working:
```
    "terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "ssh.exe",
    "terminal.integrated.shellArgs.windows": [
        "myuser@myserver.com",
        "-t",
        "cd /data/project; bash --login"
    ],

```

Please tell me how i can downgrade to the working version until this is fixed.

data.title: Can't override cmd+enter in terminal
data.body:
Tried this:

```
	{
		"key": "cmd+enter",
		"command": "workbench.action.focusActiveEditorGroup",
		"when": "terminalFocus"
	},
	{
		"key": "shift+cmd+enter",
		"command": "workbench.action.terminal.focus",
		"when": "terminalFocus"
	},
```

However, the terminal pane seems to hijack `cmd+enter`. It's not possible to override it. Same with `cmd+shift+enter`.

data.title: process.stdout.write calls don't show in the console from node2 debug sessions
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Launch debug task
2. Watch debug console

The new update appears to have broken the debug output.  Previously we would get the following when launching the debug task:

```
node --inspect=30770 --debug-brk --nolazy debugall.js 
Debugger listening on port 30770.
Warning: This is an experimental feature and could change at any time.
```

This would then be followed by the normal debug output from our project. Now when we run the debug task, the above is the only thing showing in the debug console. The application functions normally so it is running, but no output is shown.

`launch.json`:
```json
{
  "version": "0.1.0",
  "configurations": [
    {
      "name": "Debug All",
      "type": "node2",
      "program": "${workspaceRoot}/debugall.js",
      "stopOnEntry": false,
      "args": [],
      "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}/",
      "runtimeExecutable": null,
      "runtimeArgs": [
        "--nolazy"
      ],
      "env": {
        "NODE_ENV": "development",
        "LOGSQL": "false",
        "USE_COMPRESSION": "false",
      },
      "sourceMaps": false,
      "outDir": null,
      "console": "internalConsole"
    }
  ]
}
```

data.title: Add action to show inline all diagnostics in file.
data.body:
`F8` and `Shift + F8` navigation between diagnostic is really nice but sometimes it would be useful to have nice view of all diagnostics in current file. 

Looks like it would be fairly simple to implement, just one additional editor action in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/2a40036dbb34aac4f5aefbe999c21f2eaf76c59b/src/vs/editor/contrib/gotoError/browser/gotoError.ts, I could try implementing it if this feature idea is accepted.

- Extensions:

2. Install Visual Studio Code.
3. Open any folder which is a git repository.
